DataElement.preferredName: Metastatic Malignant Neoplasm to the Brain Integer::4 Week Negation Disease Progression Post Magnetic Resonance Imaging Cancer Therapeutic Procedure Assessment Indicator
DataElement.preferredDefinition: The indicator response regarding whether a patient diagnosed with brain metastases or leptomeningeal metastases and have been treated show any evidence of disease progression within 4 weeks after completion of treatment.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Metastatic Malignant Neoplasm to the Brain Integer::4 Week Negation Disease Progression Post Magnetic Resonance Imaging Cancer Therapeutic Procedure Assessment
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: A malignant neoplasm that has spread to the brain from another anatomic site or system. The majority are carcinomas (usually lung or breast carcinomas)._A number with no fractional part, including the negative and positive numbers as well as zero.::4_Any period of seven consecutive days._An operation in which a term denies or inverts the meaning of another term or construction._The worsening of a disease over time._Happening at a time subsequent to a reference time; later in time or order._Imaging that uses radiofrequency waves and a strong magnetic field rather than x-rays to provide amazingly clear and detailed pictures of internal organs and tissues. The technique is valuable for the diagnosis of many pathologic conditions, including cancer, heart and vascular disease, stroke, and joint and musculoskeletal disorders._Any intervention for management of a malignant neoplasm._The final result of a determination of the value, significance, or extent of.

ObjectClass.preferredName: Metastatic Malignant Neoplasm to the Brain
ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: The spread of a neoplasm from a primary site to the brain. The most common primary tumors metastatic to brain include lung cancer(adenosquamous and small cell especially), breast cancer, melanoma, renal cancer and colon cancer. Metastases are frequently found at the grey/white junction. They are usually well demarcated from the brain parenchyma. The majority of metastases (greater than 75%) are found supratentorially with the minority (less than 10%) found in the brainstem. The patients present with signs and symptoms referable to either increased intracranial pressure or focal pathology. A contrast enhanced MRI will give the best view of suspected metastatic cancers. Therapy for the metastatic cancer is based upon the therapy that would be or has been given to the primary cancer. In any event corticosteroids can be useful for reduction of patients' symptoms. (Kaye, Laws Brain Tumors Churchill Livingstone 1995)

Concepts.longName: Metastatic Malignant Neoplasm in the Brain
Concepts.definition: A malignant neoplasm that has spread to the brain from another anatomic site or system. The majority are carcinomas (usually lung or breast carcinomas).

Property.preferredName: Integer::4 Week Negation Disease Progression Post Magnetic Resonance Imaging Cancer Therapeutic Procedure Assessment
Property.preferredDefinition: A number with no fractional part, including the negative and positive numbers as well as zero.::4:Any period of seven consecutive days.:An operation in which a term denies or inverts the meaning of another term or construction.:The worsening of a disease over time.:Happening at a time subsequent to a reference time; later in time or order.:Imaging that uses radiofrequency waves and a strong magnetic field rather than x-rays to provide amazingly clear and detailed pictures of internal organs and tissues. The technique is valuable for the diagnosis of many pathologic conditions, including cancer, heart and vascular disease, stroke, and joint and musculoskeletal disorders.:Any intervention for management of a malignant neoplasm.:The final result of a determination of the value, significance, or extent of.

Concepts.definition: A number with no fractional part, including the negative and positive numbers as well as zero.
Any period of seven consecutive days.
An operation in which a term denies or inverts the meaning of another term or construction.
A process that manifests as the worsening of a disease over time.
Happening at a time subsequent to a reference time; later in time or order.

Imaging that uses radiofrequency waves and a strong magnetic field rather than x-rays to provide detailed pictures of internal organs and tissues. The technique is valuable for the diagnosis of many pathologic conditions, including cancer, heart and vascular disease, stroke, and joint and musculoskeletal disorders.
Any intervention for management of a malignant neoplasm.
The final result of a determination of the value, significance, or extent of.

Concepts.longName: Yes, No, or Not Applicable Response
Concepts.definition: A response or indicator that can have a value of yes, no, or not applicable.

RepresentationTerm.changeDescription: 10.2.20 TL changed WFS from RETIRED PHASED OUT to RETIRED ARCHIVED. Retired DBW 04-27-2016 per Tina Taylor approved by Dianne Reves

ValueDomain.changeDescription: 3/12/17 jk added Standard reg status; ownership transfered from CTEP to NCI Standards with concurrence of CTEP/Brian Campbell. 8/3/2015 Corrections made to VD in order to restore to original format: removed C49486 as rep term and replaced with C49797; restored long name and definition per Dianne Reeves/tt.

ReferenceDocuments.name: If the patient had brain meta
ReferenceDocuments.description: If the patient had brain metastases or leptomeningeal metastases,have the metastases been treated and is there no MRI evidence of progression for at least 4 weeks after  treatment is complete?

ReferenceDocuments.name: NRG_CRF_Text 1
ReferenceDocuments.description: If the patient was previously diagnosed with brain metastases, were those metastases treated and is there no clinical or radiographic evidence of progression prior to enrollment

ReferenceDocuments.name: CRF Text 2
ReferenceDocuments.description: Radiographic demonstration of improvement upon the completion of CNS-directed therapy and no evidence of interim progression between the completion of CNS-directed therapy and the screening radiographic study

ReferenceDocuments.name: NRG_CRF_TEXT2
ReferenceDocuments.description: If the patient was previously diagnosed with brain metastases, were those metastases treated and is there no clinical or radiographic evidence of progression within 30 days prior to enrollment

ReferenceDocuments.name: NRG_eCRF_Text
ReferenceDocuments.description: Does follow-up brain imaging after CNS-directed therapy shows evidence of progression?

ReferenceDocuments.name: NRG_eCRF_Text_1
ReferenceDocuments.description: Does follow-up brain imaging after CNS-directed therapy shows no evidence of progression, and have they been off steroids for at least 4 weeks prior to Step 1 registration and remain clinically stable?

ReferenceDocuments.name: NRG_eCRF_Text_2
ReferenceDocuments.description: Does follow-up brain imaging, completed no later than 14 days prior to enrollment, show no evidence of progression and they have been off steroids within 14 days prior to enrollment?

ReferenceDocuments.name: CRF Text 3
ReferenceDocuments.description: If the patient has treated brain metastases and resolved associated symptoms, is post-therapeutic imaging stable for at least 6 months following therapy, prior to study registration?

ReferenceDocuments.name: NRG_CRF_TEXT_3
ReferenceDocuments.description: If the patient was previously diagnosed with brain metastases, were those lesions treated or resolved and is there no clinical or radiographic evidence of progression prior to registration?

ReferenceDocuments.name: NRG_CRF_Text4
ReferenceDocuments.description: Does follow-up brain imaging after CNS-directed therapy show no evidence of progression and the patient is stable off steroids for at least one month?

ReferenceDocuments.name: NRG_eCRF_Text_4
ReferenceDocuments.description: Does follow-up brain imaging after CNS-directed therapy show no evidence of progression and is the patient stable off steroids for at least one month?

ReferenceDocuments.name: NRG_eCRF_Text_3
ReferenceDocuments.description: Does follow-up brain imaging after CNS-directed therapy show no evidence of progression?
